title: Adams defends rat traps amid animal rights outcry
text:
Adams argues that drowning, while admittedly not pleasant, is a more humane way to kill rats than poison, which leads to a painful death that can take weeks. | AP Photo Adams defends rat traps amid animal rights outcry

Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams hit back at animal rights activists outraged over his gleeful slaughter of rats, saying their sympathy for the much-hated rodents shows a blindness to the suffering of black communities.

“We can never put rats over children, and I am not going to do that,” Adams said Thursday on WNYC’s The Brian Lehrer show.

Story Continued Below

The rat fight started when Adams last week trotted out the sodden corpses of dozens of rats captured around Brooklyn Borough Hall — promoting a new trap that lures the creatures and then drowns them in a mix of water and alcohol.

That earned the 2021 mayoral hopeful the ire of animal rights groups, who attacked him in a letter for “cheerleading for the killing of living animals” by showing off the dead rat stew.

But Adams said he can’t afford to feel much pity for the furry pests when mothers in African American neighborhoods are waking up to find rats “gnawing on their babies.”

“We see a rat every once in a while in affluent areas, but when you go to the African American and impoverished parts of the city and communities of color, you see a crisis,” he said. “There are people who don’t want to go into their homes. There are rats coming through our stoves, coming through our toilets. Families are traumatized.”

While rat drowning may seem like an unlikely wedge issue in the upcoming mayoral race, the animal rights groups now infuriated with Adams have proved influential before — helping to sink Christine Quinn’s 2013 mayoral campaign after she opposed banning horse-drawn carriages in the city.

“He’s creating straw man arguments to defend his barbaric practice of drowning animals, and promoting violence towards animals,” said Matt Dominguez, political adviser at Voters for Animal Rights.

“For him to claim that this is about children versus rats is insane. He’s doing that to justify his bad behavior,” he said. “Don’t torture animals, and don’t sadistically carry their bodies out to the press and display them as trophies.”

Adams argues that drowning, while admittedly not pleasant, is a more humane way to kill rats than poison, which leads to a painful death that can take weeks.

The animal rights groups counter that sterilization in combination with cleaning up the city’s trash problem is the more effective way to rein in the city’s notoriously large rat population.

The city has tried a range of methods, which also include suffocating rats with dry ice, in a decadeslong but mostly unsuccessful battle against the rat scourge.

Prior to the dead rat incident, Adams had positioned himself as a champion of animal rights — touting his vegan eating habits, pushing for the city to reduce meat consumption and opposing the gassing of geese in Prospect Park.

“For God’s sake, I led a march in Prospect Park to stop killing geese,” he said Thursday. He went on to invoke the psychological theory of Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs to argue that concern about being “nice to rats” is a “luxury.”

Animal advocates were particularly offended because, for the last six months, Adams has been approaching animal protection groups to ask for support for his mayoral campaign, Dominguez said.

“He’s been two faced,” he said. “We do not trust anything that he says anymore.”

Edita Birnkrant, executive director of NYCLASS — the group that led the charge against horse-drawn carriages — said the groups are sympathetic to the problems rats cause in neighborhoods, but Adams’ rat trap is not going to make a dent.

“We just see this as kind of a drop in the bucket, no pun intended,” Birnkrant said. “As long as we are poorly handling garbage disposal and piling up hundreds of bags of garbage on the street, we’re going to have this problem.”
